description.text:
After some prints and test i have found out that the Z-axis is no more synchronize. That is not a surprise because we have two stepper Motors for the Z-axis and after some time they are no more synchronize. For that reason I misplaced the Hotbet. After some settings with the caliper and folding rule I was dissatisfied and make this small helping Thing. You need only a folding rule and dissected it.

I have dissected the folding rule at 10,5 cm (you can let it be longer if you want) and insert it in the Holder. Assemble it, finish. Now I can check the z axis before the Print.

If you have a problem or an improvement for this thing please let me now it.

Nach einigen Druckvorgänge und Tests ist mir aufgefallen das die Z-Achse nicht mehr richtig eingestellt ist. Ist nicht verwunderlich da es sich um zwei Schrittmotoren handelt und diese sich mit der Zeit einfach verstellen. Dadurch habe ich mir das Duckbett ebenfalls verstellt. Nach einigen Versuchen mit Schieblehre und Zollstock hatte ich es leid und habe diese einfach Hilfe konstruiert. Man benötigt nur einen Zollstock den man einfach zersägt.

Ich habe den Zollstock bei 10,5 cm (kann auch länger gelassen werden) abgesägt und in den Halter gesteckt. Montiert Fertig. So kann ich vor jedem Druck die Z Achse kontrollieren.

Schreibt wenn es noch was zu verbessern gibt.

It is very easy to Control and adjustment the Z-axis with this.
Here the approach:
Step 1:
In the Printer menu to the function “Quick Settings” Menu to the “Home All”
Check if the Z-axis is on both sides at the same level.

If it is everything is ok. You only need to do is the bed Leveling.

Step 2:
If the Z-axis is not on the Same level than go in the “Quick Settings” Menu to the “Disable Stepper”.
Now turn only the on the right threaded rod to adjustment the Z-axis to the same level like the left (the side of the Z-axis end switch) one.
If the Z-axis end switch on the right side than only adjust on the left threaded rod.
Test the level with the “Quick Settings” Menu to the “Home All”.
If it is everything is ok. You only need to do is the bed Leveling.

If the Z-axis is not on the Same level repeat Step 2.

With this little Thing you don't need to adjust the Z-axis end switch.

Die es ist ganz einfach die Z Achse zu kontrollieren und einzustellen.
Hier die Anleitung:
Schritt 1:
Im Drucker Menü zur Funktion “Quick Settings” hier zu “Home All”
Prüfen ob die Z-Achse auf beiden Seiten gleich ist.

Ist alles in Ordnung dann muss nur noch das Druckbett eingestellt werden.

Schritt 2:
Sind die beiden Seiten der Z-Achse nicht auf gleicher Höhe gehe im Druckermenü auf “Quick Settings“ und anschließend auf den Menüpunkt “Disable Stepper“.
Jetzt an der rechten Gewindestange so lange drehen bis die linke Seite (Endschalter der Z-Achse) mit der rechten wieder gleich ist.
Sollte der Z-Achsen Endschalter auf der rechten Seite sein dann muss man an der linken Gewindestange drehen.
Testen ob die Einstellung so in Ordnung ist mit der Funktion “Home All“.

Ist die Einstellung immer noch nicht in Ordnung wiederhole Schritt 2.

Ist alles in Ordnung dann muss nur noch das Druckbett eingestellt werden.

Mit dieser kleinen Einstellhilfe muss der Endschalter der Z-Achse nicht verstellt werden.

title: Touch Screen Case for Landzo 7 Inch

description.text:
This is a remix of the LCD monitor case for the 7in Waveshare touchscreen which I adapted to the 7 inch Landzo touchscreen which I use on my HyperCube build https://www.thingiverse.com/make:332719

The changes include narrowing the case by 6mm and adjusting the hole positions to be correct for the Landzo. I also added mounting points on the back of the case which support the case for the Raspberry Pi https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:922740

I also created a bracket which mounts to the 2020 railing and supports the case quite easily, Two of the brackets will need to be printed.

When attaching the Pi case to the LCD case I used 3mm nylon standoffs but any spacer will work and an M3 screw will thread into the mounting points on the back of the case. I created the back such that it is solid but can easily be drilled out to allow an M3 screw to attach to the case.

SPECIAL NOTE: The LCD board does fit in the reduced space provide but it is necessary to work on it like a puzzle to get it into place. All the screws also fit but a thin screwdriver will be needed for 1 or 2 of the screws on the side with the connectors holding the LCD board in place.

title: Solder Fume Extractor (by sneakypoo) CPU Fan Adapter Plate

description.text:
This variant is a print of the original Solder Fume Extractor at 68 percent using an old CPU fan (which is an 80 x 80 fan). This CPU fan however as you can see has a bit larger fan cage due to the design. This piece I designed goes between the fan and the rest of the assembly allowing the fan to interface cleanly (without air leaks).

I made it thick enough to allow for M3 brass heat sets to be used negating the need for nuts and bolts. Used 8 - M3 brass heatsets, 4 - M3 12mm black oxide screws, and 4 - 6mm black oxide screws. Made for a clean installation.

Works great, and although it's a more compact model overall, it still draws the soldering fumes while sitting about 8 inches away from the workspace. Don't have a large desk so this more compact version works well for my application.

Thanks BTW to sneakypoo for the design. Very nice. Be sure to download the rest of the Solder Fume Extractor parts from his thing. Only my adapter plate is downloadable from this thing.

I printed this on a balanced setting with 50% infill. You can make it a heavier whorl by increasing the infill density. I used a 7mm raft on both, which I found was necessary to keep the spindle nice and straight.

title: Hictop E3D V6 Drop in Carriage Replacement- Simple and Convenient Upgrade

description.text:
Not yet printed this exact version but I have had a lot of success with previous version. Pictures are from first version and before I tidied it up. I'm about to print the version herein and will post pictures of the final product and maybe some example prints. Ya need a bunch of nuts and bolts but I didnt need anything in addition to what already came with the HicTop printer off Amazon.

Significantly decreased weight and allows use of the E3D V6 hotend for significantly increased speed and quality.
Can use both the stock hictop fans as-is.
Stiff x-axis belt holder which is much less likely to deform or break than stock and doesnt require weight of bolting.

Holds the nozzle more rigidly by making use of the E3D fan shroud to grip the fins (decreasing nozzle deflection increases print accuracy)

I originally had this as a bolt-on similar to stock but figured I might as well integrate it.
Clip for zip-tie so your cords dont get dislocated or contacts bent.
You can modify the stock parts of the hictop with the RepRap Champion kit to fashion the remode extruder. Dont have a fancy design yet cause it works pretty well just clamped to my enclosure but that will be my next step.

Info on the E3D here.
http://e3d-online.com/E3D-v6

I use this with my RepRap Champion Bowden Extruder:

author: PBeis

description.text:
Remix of a remix.

Made a few adjustments to the move stand portion. Relocated the cable channels and replaced the round opening with a rectangular one to fit an angled mini USB plug. Also narrowed the circumference and flattened the bottom of the wells to give a more snug and secure fit to the move controllers. With the usb plugs glued in place it has a satisfying 'snap-in' and secure fit.

Cables used:
2x https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00F2GR2H6/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
1x https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01222EM7A/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1

A few caveats:
I didn't have the angled plugs when I redesigned the holes so I measured another USB mini plug I had laying around. It was close in width but slightly narrower. So the plugs I used with these need a bit of trimming to fit. Also I could have added some more depth to the base to accommodate their height. Again some trimming helps the fit. They still stick out a bit but I put rubber bumpers on the bottom anyway which gave enough clearance for them.

description.text:
Inspired by a mention from @jedishepp, and my own love of the mythology behind the Forge of Solus Prime, I decided to create the Titan Hammer. In the pictures, I have it paired with Titan Master Sawback, who is master in both forging armor and boosting a Transformer's ability to punch through it.

The hammer fits a standard 5mm fist, and has a 5mm post on the head for storing it. I designed it in TinkerCAD in about an hour, so it is a bit simple, but it works for my purposes. would love to see some remixes.

remixed_from.author: rcolyer
remixed_from.title: Plot Function library for OpenSCAD, with Cartesian, Polar, and Axial coordinates

description.text:
This design is a rippled chalice, which could hold a drink with a safe material, or it could serve as a vase. The design is a demonstration of the axial plotting mode of my function plotting library, which allows rendering arbitrary functions to form the surfaces of objects.

Aside from the work done by the library, most of the code volume is just some trickery to round out the lip at the top. The code sections for the general chalice shape and for the ornate outer surface are actually quite simple and would be easy to adjust arbitrarily with a different functional shape, so interesting derivatives should be quite straightforward.

The parameters of the existing functions are adjustable in Customizer.

Note: The ripple_chalice.scad file uses my plotting library: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2391851

remixed_from.title: "Spriya" - High Efficiency Anet A8 Fan Duct

title: Spriya Anet A8 Fan Duct Modified for shorter nozzle height

description.text:
So I've only just got my A8, and was advised that I needed to change to standard fan duct for this one. So I printed it out (and it came out perfect) but, the overall height of the duct was too high. I have my nozzle set quite high in the block, so that it's easier to insert the filament after the extruder.
Fortunately, the original came with the blender file, so it was easy for me to remove 2mm from the top, and move the outlet nozzle's up 3mm. Re-printed and it fits (and works) perfectly.
It still looks exactly the same as the original, just not as high over all.

remixed_from.author: dbibeau
remixed_from.title: Coffee Monsta! Eats the used coffee grounds in your spent k-cups!

title: K-Cup Coffee Compost Collector on Peanut Butter Jar Lid

description.text:
This Thingie is a Double Remix!

I wanted a peanut butter jar lid for K-Cup compost collector and have adapted two other things, 1st) the lid by 3Dmigos "Screw Lid for Nutella Jar" (1001973) with 2nd) the base of dbibeau's "Coffee Monsta! Eats the used coffee grounds in your spent k-cups!" (711329).

Print both and then bolt the Coffee Monsta (or REV C TOP) to the modified Nutella lid with 3 #8 x 1/2 or 5/8 machine screws. You now have a K-Cup Compost Collector to screw onto that peanut butter jar you have because you don't have a mason jar to collect the K-Cup grounds.

Both items will take about 3 hours to print. Coffee Monsta is thing 711329, search on that. A year from now the top will degrade and break down and a new one can be bolted onto to peanut butter jar lid.

I buy one pound Smucker's organic creamy, a standard size glass jar; composting collecting is a good repurposing of a peanut butter glass jar! In the photo you see a green "fill your own" K-cup, if the scraper is ever redesigned (it was, see update below) then the new one is bolted onto the lid, no need to print both parts. Hmmm, what other tops can now fit on a peanut butter jar?

UPDATE 6/25: the photo features a modified TOP to print, added a 30 mm diameter flat surface at the top to scrape the inside corners of the K-Cup. Tap the cup until most coffee has fallen out and then twist back and forth to "scrape" the inside corners of the cup!

Again, I was able to create this quickly from the work of 3Dmigos and dbibeau. Thanks very much for posting your work to Thingiverse! Credit others!

author: OnTheGulf

print_settings.Notes:: I like PLA but that's all I know.  See all notes in the description

title: Traxxas Slash 2WD Part 2555 Modified Rear Suspension Arms

description.text:
Update: Also see part 3631 for front suspension arms.

PLEASE READ ALL NOTES. I am very proud of this part. It took me several weeks to optimize. Any feedback of actual field testing and pictures of breakages will be GREATLY APPRECIATED. Please keep me in mind and help me improve this part for all the bashers out there.

Part v11 is an 11th generation part, taking into account breakage data and feedback from Karnite. It has fewer holes at the breakage points, plus the chassis screw encasement is just a bit reduced at the outer ranges of its swing.

Part v10 is a 10th generation, weight reduced part with the thickest ends possible around the chassis pins which has not yet been field tested but I believe it will be super durable. Part 10 has left and right versions. Its weight is close to factory weight but maybe 10% heavier. Part 82 is an older solid version, field tested, and quite a bit heavier than the Traxxas part. This part broke around the chassis pin when I did a 6' tall ramp, so I made version 10. Any thicker and you will need Aluminum or a different printing material.

I use this with the low gravity kit for the Traxxas Slash 2WD. I start by screwing the longest chassis pin in at the back end of the car (backwards from Traxxas), and start the shorter wheel pin at the front end of the car (same as Traxxas). This allows me to replace the part much easier when it breaks.

Please print this with PLA as solid (90% density) on high quality setting. Use supports to ensure the holes are round. Use a 1/8" drill bit to clean out the end holes for the pins and a 1/16" or 5/64" to clean out the middle suspension screw hole. DO NOT OVERSIZE the holes which weakens the part! If you use a 5/64" for the suspension hole and it is too big, then try heating around the hole for a couple of seconds with a lighter or small grill torch, then squeeze above and below the hole with pliers to make the hole smaller.
I created this part because the Traxxas original suspension hole kept stripping out. Filling the hole with super glue then re-drilling the hole nice and small can also work sometimes.

Printer:

XYZWare Da Vinci Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

High

Infill:

High (90% density rectilinear)

Notes:

I like PLA but that's all I know. See all notes in the description
See all notes in the description about drilling
Inventor is a wonderful tool. Step by step, hour by hour...iterative design. I broke 5 of these before I landed on a pretty solid design (v8) and since have made v8.2 and v10. (included)

description.text:
Apparently Razer are making similar cat ears for their headphones, so I made some which should fit on any headphones with an over head band.

Print the ear pieces and optionally can colour change @28.2mm to get the rim a different colour.

Get a pair of thin hair bands/bobbles and superglue them into the slots on the backs of each ear. These bands can wrap under the headphone band and hook onto the little hooks on the bottom front of the ear.
https://www.amazon.co.uk/Piece-Bobbles-Elastics-Black-Metal/dp/B01M7QL0KU/ref=sr_1_3_a_it?ie=UTF8&qid=1520589807&sr=8-3&keywords=bobbles+thin+no+snag

description.text: You will need an M5x20 countersunk screw and a washer to secure the wheel to the base, and obviously a 608 bearing. The base is designed to be adhered to the side of an aquarium (I own two gerbils and a 20L aquarium is ideal for them) with double sided tape, preferably some strong 3M tape. This should use around 150g of PLA for the wheel, plus around 25g for the base, if you are printing at 30% infill, which is definitely more than enough. Will possibly add a free standing base in the future. Bear in mind that this is a large wheel and you preferably need a printer with a 200x200 base since this is a 180mm diameter wheel.

title: Traxxas Slash 2WD Modified 3736 Front Steering Blocks (L & R)

description.text:
PLEASE SEND ME FEEDBACK AND PICTURES OF BROKEN PARTS! THANKS! Or stop by in a month if you are still up and running like me!

I modified this on 7/20/2017 taking into account user feedback that the socket for the bearings and the holes for the screws was a bit too small.

This is a modified design for Traxxas part 3736. It is much thicker than the original part and I believe it is also more durable even when printed with PLA due to this extra thickness.

There is actually a left and a right part, since the thicker part tends to interfere with other parts of the steering or suspension and needs slight knotches cut out on the arm.

Printer:

XYZWare Da Vinci Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

High

Infill:

High (90% density rectilinear)

Notes:

I do not have a heated bed and print with PLA.

I use BuildTak on my print bed which is AWESOME. Did I say AWESOME? I love it so much. I used to hate 3d printing before I started using that stuff. It was SO FRUSTRATING.
Now, ALL prints work the first time after calibrating once with it. Before I think I had a success rate of maybe 75%, even with masking tape, packaging tape, carpet tape, and glue stick, and all that stuff took up a lot of time. Now it is so easy. Seriously, just buy the stuff. Let me know if it works for you and changed your whole 3d printing outlook!
You will need to make sure the bearings are settled all the way down in the hole. Scrape out any residual plastic from the bearing holes so the bearings fit deep and snug.

Lots of passion. I wanted a design that was better than the factory design and would not break. So far, so good!

I used Inventor. The hardest thing I had to learn was creating a plane at a certain angle from another plane.

Guess what? I only own a millimeter ruler. I eyeball down to the 1/10 of a millimeter and often get it close. If you like my work, please send me a caliper so I can have an easier time. :-)

description.text:
I didnt have any m3 screws to mount my usb controller for my racing sim handbrake, so i made this.
It is designed to hold the controller in place and keep the solder points from touching the bottom. Its has a hole out of the back to feed the usb through; however, i did not make wholes for the button wires because i only need one and you may need more. So i would open in tinkercad and add holes where needed. i may fix that in a future update.

This is a 3D representation of the wave function resulting from the classic double-slit experiment of quantum mechanics. It provides a physical manipulative to give a more concrete representation of an important experiment that is usually given a very abstract treatment. It also makes for a nice pair of display pieces for a select crowd.

This was generated using my plotting library: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2391851

title: Front fork drop out spacer 9mm axle

description.text:
This is a spacer to put between the drop-outs on your front forks when you've removed the wheel. Useful when transporting your bike (especially if sending in a bike-box on an airplane) - it stops the forks getting bent.
Was packing my bike & couldn't find one so made this.
I measured my drop-out/axle on my commuter bike with digital calipers and it read 8.8mm, so the maximum width of this spacer is 8.8mm and seems to give a snug fit when installed - see photos. It is too small for a 10mm drop-out/axle
NB in the photos the forks are rotated to face backwards as it fits better in the bike-box this way.
Made on Autodesk Fusion360

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

MakerGear M2

author: drandybuck

description.text:
Here is a E3D V6 Bowden Collet I designed because of my issue with the Orion Delta when I first bought it used, Mine was melted and I needed to replace. This will have to be printed at .05 - .1 Micron in order to print it. I would use either ABS or PETG as they are more flexible than PLA. Print with a brim only if you are having adhesion issues otherwise print as it is.

This is a temporary fix until you can get a real one. It will be a tight fit for the tube but the first time you take it out it may snap.

What you will need to print this is a 0.2 Nozzle and your favorite PLA, That's it.

description.text: Scanned in the 3D photobooth at the MakerBot retail store in Soho!

This is a replica window from a O scale Plasticville house found on many Plasticville O scale/gauge/Lionel train homes. I took the measurements right from a Plasticville window, It fits perfectly into the window hole of a store bought Plasticville kit. Great for restoring a vintage Plasticville home, or for use on any 1:48th scale buildings! I am a Plasticville fanatic! I have many of their buildings on my Lionel layout, and wanted to make my own based off of their buildings. I'm planning on posting many Plasticville replicas! I call it the Plasticville Project. I wasn't going to post any of these files until I was completely done with a "kit" but decided to just post them as I create them instead. Stay tuned, I will be posting this entire house you can print. They are easily scale able to HO or whatever scale or gauge your layout is! Also great for under your Christmas tree! Print one today, don't delay!

description.text:
If you have kids or ever lived with anyone who was messy one of the main things you loose often other than keys and your wallet is the TV remote.

When I ask the kids to clean the remote is always somewhere different. This was created so there is a single spot that the remote goes and "should" always be in this spot.

This one was made to be on a table mounted or as just a stand. I will mount mine because the stand would just get misplaced also.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

20

Notes:

I used a volcano .6 tip printing at .3 , I am sure you can print less than .3 but I really didn't care that it looked perfect and just that it worked.

NOTE: My bridging is pretty good so I didn't need supports. If you do not you may want to consider it.
For the mounted option I used a 3m removable strip. Just peel, connect to the base and mount. Enjoy having higher chance of finding your remote!

I give you the ultimate calibration comb! :-)
Sometimes you just need something like this to test out slicer settings or printing troubles. AND maybe you have very specific questions about tolerances etc, anyway, now you can make your own personal calibration model, with just the right zone of values you're struggling with.

sometimes I have a very specific range of values I am trying to slice/print...and I want to know "what if I just add 0.01mm to that wall, will it slice THEN??!!?" well now I have a fast way to answer those questions. AND you do too!

Headphone batteries no longer hold a charge? Having trouble finding replacements because someone put square ends on them? If you try to put regular AAA NiMH they won't turn on. Why the heck is that? Well there are tiny little switches at the negative end of the battery compartments that must be depressed. Print this object, cut it in half with diagonal cutters, then trim both pieces to fit (22mm in length). Shove the half-square end down to the bottom of the compartment and slid back to engage the switch. Now you can use garden variety AAA NiMH batteries. Other types will fit, but don't put anything but NiMH back in the charger. You have been warned.

description.text:
I used the customizable rocket nozzle generator by waterside to generate a convergence divergence nozzle to work with a black powder rocket engine. I printed the engine in PLA, and despite its low melting temperature, the motor held up very well and has no damage. The integrity is in tact after firing it and I would consider it re-usable. The engine had a burn time of about five seconds and an estimated 20g of thrust.

Test video in slow motion.

The Idle Hands fidget spinner - Patterned after the pagan symbol for love and fertility. Show it to all your friends. Confirm what your conservative friends already suspected, that fidget spinners are indeed evil.

Printed at 0.2mm layer height. No special settings, but I did find that the caps print best with the bearing spindle down, and supports on. This is due to the small concave surface on the face of both caps that doesn't print well if face down. Bearing is a tight fit but it will go. The bearing cut-out is at exactly 22mm.

To complete this fidget you'll need (5) m4 nuts (because that's what I had available) and a 608 bearing. Enjoy, and be sure to ROCK ON!

Prusa

Printer:

0.2mm

description.text:
A simple hollow can cooler / can coozy or whatever you call them. Fits a standard north american soda can (2.6 inch diameter). May also hold beer cans :)

I created this design to experiment with "spiral vase" printing, where the printer builds upwards in a spiral instead of printing layer by layer. There's a 1mm base on the bottom of the can that's printed "normally", everything above that is printed as a spiral vase.

The STL files look like a solid can (and that's what they are) but once you load it into your slicer and preview it in spiral vase mode, which takes off top surfaces and removes infill, it'll make sense.

I've uploaded two files. The "spiral" one was the first attempt at a can cooler, it fits the can beautifully but doesn't really do much to impede vertical airflow against the outside of the can. The "zigzag" one may better in theory, but it's a tigher fit on the can as it's much less "springy".

There's probably all sorts of random/fun patterns you could come up with.

As with all of my uploads, the OpenSCAD files are a disorganized mess, and I apologize.

Printer:

AM8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

0%

Notes:

Use spiral vase mode, a 0.5mm extrusion width, no infill or top layer, and a 1mm thick (or greater) bottom layer. Note that I used a 0.5mm nozzle on my printer to do the print.

If you change the extrusion width, change the "line_width" value in the OpenSCAD source and generate a new STL.

title: Raspberry Pi camera mount for the Nop Head Mendel90 3D Printer

description.text:
This bracket is a simple clip together print which allows you to mount your Raspberry Pi camera on your Mendel90 without requiring any screws. The resulting image gives a good view of the extruder. PLEASE NOTE:
Unfortunately this was designed for the original Raspberry Pi camera and does not fit the newer versions.

I produced this design to allow people setting up OctoPrint / OctoPi on their Nop Head Mendel 90 to attach the Raspberry Pi camera without having to drill any holes. It gives an excellent view of the extruder in action and requires no additional screws, nuts or bolts.  
This design works best when printed in a 0.2mm layer height and personally I used PLA but I would imagine the design is suitable for any material.  
I found no support / scaffolding is necessary except for camera_mount_hinge which requires a little support to print the pegs.  
The bracket should fit snugly but loose enough to slide up and down on your Mendel without scratching the frame. Once you have found the best viewing position add a tiny amount of blue tack in the gap in the bracket, then when you push it back in place on your Mendel it will stay still.

title: Cryptex
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a four digit cryptex. It is designed with slight tolerances so little to no post-printing work is required. When all the wheels are lined up to display the proper code, it can be easily opened and closed. If the proper code is not selected, the box stays locked and cannot be opened. The password used to lock the cryptex can be set to any 4 digit number containing the numbers 0-7.

Print:
1 cryptex case
1 cryptex case part 2
1 cryptex lock
4 cryptex keys
4 cryptex number hex nut

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1-0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Only the cryptex case part 2 requires supports. Using rafts will increase likelihood that the parts won't come off the build plate while printing (I used rafts), but may decrease the quality of the bottoms of the prints.

Additional note: Whatever number you put over the slot in the cryptex key will be the password.

description.text:
A second lucky pig bobble - see thing:1828478. The bobble is composed of two parts that print more readily than the original. A recursive curve is used as a spring. The bobble was designed to work when printed in PLA but adjustments can be made for other materials.

The spring was calculated using the program included with thing:2377518 - Closed Recursive Curves. The input parameters were: 5,10,4,180,2,17,0,1,0,2,bobble_base.stl". The final "2" in the list is the radius of the spring - 2 mm. To make a stiffer spring increase the radius to 2.5 mm.

title: Smol Drone v1 (97.6mm Quadcopter for 66mm Props and 7mm Motors)

description.text:
This frame is designed for 7*20mm motors, parrot mini drone propellers (66mm props) and a e011 flight controller.

Other Versions;
v1 - you're already here ;)
v2 - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2393885
v3 - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2395843
v4 -

Things you need;

  • Motors
  • Flight Controller
  • Propellers (Under 68mm)
  • Rubber band
  • JST Connector

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15%

How to Build it

Step 1, solder your JST connector to the flight controller.
Step 2, take your flight controller and stick it in the middle using hot glue, velcro or anything to stick it down.
Step 3, put in the motors and route the wires to the flight controller through the holes and plug them in.
Step 4, put JST connector through the back hole before putting on the top plate.
Step 5, rubber band the top plate and frame together using the indents.
Step 6, put the battery on the bottom.
Step 7 - FLY!!!

remixed_from.title: Shadows of Brimstone sidebag & town token holder

title: Collapsible Shadows of Brimstone sidebag & town token holder

description.text:
I wanted a token tray for a Shadows of Brimstone insert I'm trying to finish up. I only have 40mm of height left to work with so I altered BasHamer's design to make it collapsible. I also removed two of the token shafts, so the trays rest mostly flat at the back. The town location diameter was increased as well, making the tokens easier to remove. The Fusion 360 project file is included with the STLs.

Print the two parts, then place the outer ring over the inner to let them rest on a flat surface, with the inner ring twisted slightly counter-clockwise. To stow it, hold the outer ring with one hand and spin the inner ring clockwise to lock it in place. Unlock it by spinning counter-clockwise again. For game use, lift the inner ring until the lip catches on the outer ring, then spin clockwise to lock it in place.

UPDATE (2017-07-01):
I decided to reduce the excessive number of latches by 3, which works much better now. I only re-printed the outer ring and can twist the rings with just enough force to latch them at the bottom (to stow) or the top (to display), without risk of having them come apart. The STLs and Fusion files have been updated.

Wilson II

No

No

12%

The overhangs were designed with printable angles that should not require supports.

author: GoJimi

title: Yagi Antenna FPV 1.2GHz with assorted mounts

description.text:
This thing is a yagi antenna for FPV flying. It is a simple light-weight 4 element design and works well for medium to long range flights (20km+). The antenna can be printed in 3 of the common frequencies - 1200 MHz, 1280 MHz & 1360 MHz. Thanks to IBCrazy for providing the antenna info.

There are assorted mounts available which press on to the end of the antenna. The GoPro mount works with the standard GoPro style adapters. The 4x4cm flat mount can be attached to a flat surface using 4 bolts. The 3x2.25in mount has been designed specifically for a servo city tilt mechanism (https://www.servocity.com/spt400-tilt-system) and can be attached using velcro. Please message me for a custom mount, happy to help.

16SWG Copper Wire (1.62mm diameter) x 1m

SMA RG316 Coaxial Cable x 30cm

Heat Shrink

Zip Tie x 1

1. Choose your desired frequency (1200,1280 or 1360) and check the images for the corresponding picture for the antenna element lengths.
  2. Cut 3 pieces of copper wire to the 1st, 3rd & 4th lengths shown on the picture. Eg. For 1280MHz, cut 3 pieces to 112.8mm, 104.1mm & 95.5mm.
  3. Insert the pieces of copper wire into the matching holes of the printed yagi frame.
  4. Push the copper wire through the holes so that the half way point sits at the TOP of the yagi frame. Eg. For 1280MHz, 56.4mm of the copper wire will be above the yagi frame.
  5. Create a dipole using a piece of RG316 coaxial cable. The length of the dipole is shown in the 2nd position of the corresponding picture. Eg. For 1280MHz, the dipole will be 112.0mm in length.
  6. Add a 10mm piece of heat shrink around the inner conductor/wire join.
  7. Insert the dipole ground element into the yagi frame.
  8. Push the dipole down so that the coaxial cable sits in the channel on the top of the yagi frame. The center of the coaxial cable should be at the top of the yagi frame.
  9. Add a zip tie around the coaxial cable.
  10. Add a piece of heat shrink around the dipole holder.

title: P3Steel Electronics Enclosure (MKS SBase 1.4 + 2 channel relay mounts)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update 1: While I still have not printed this, I have uploaded a screenshot of my assembly with the enclosure mounted on a P3Steel along with another screenshot showing the twist fasteners.

Description: This enclosure is designed for a MKS Sbase version 1.4 board. It features twist fasteners for securing it to the frame of a P3Steel 3D printer. Additionally, for power control of LEDs (and anything else) there is a mount for a 2 channel relay. The case cover on the outside currently has a grill, but I have plans to included a mount for a 40mm fan in the future. The cover snaps on via indents in the bottom case. There are pairs of holes along the outer facing wall of the case to use as zip tie points for wire management.

Feedback is greatly appreciated. Thanks everybody and happy making!

description.text:
This is a remix of the Filament Cleaner by @Rafel. I took the STL file and copied the profile, however created the part from scratch using Solidworks. The previous version would not sit over top of the "BCN3DSigma-M01C02.0P07A Bowden entry top" part on the printer, causing it to rock and not be stable. The clearance it has was 10mm off the printer floor, the actual designed parts take up 10.5mm based on BCN3D solidwork files, however on my printer they actually sit just under 11mm, so I have designed the clearance to be 11.5mm.

I have included a mid-detailed STL export, and the Solidworks design.
Edit/chop/change as you see fit.
If you can think of another improvement, please let me know, I am happy to modify and push out something else if it will work better.

Added different text down the side of the part compared to the original.

BCN3D

Yes

Notes:

Resolution and Infill likely not critical. Supports are required due to the large overhang.

You could put a piece of double sided tape under the feet of this to hold it onto the base of your printer if you want, or just let it sit freely. Depending what your printer is doing, it might rattle - see how you go. The filament goes down from the top, so friction on the filament may hold it enough.

Just fold a piece of foam into the gap and cut to suit, so the filament gets wiped as it goes into the machine floor.
Start of the print. Printing using Simplify3D, used Cura for the original version, will see what differences there are.

Hi!

made a ring flash for my camera (canon 40D with ex 580 clone), but it should fit most set ups with similar sized. Took me many hours to model, then many more hours to print, but I'm very happy with the results.

If you want to adapt it to your model, all you have to do is fiddle with the "adaptor" part to make it fit on your flash. The other parts should be good to fit most cameras and lenses.

Printed it at .2 line height, .4 shell thickness and 15 infill, and once together, it's pretty solid You might want to print the front part (I named it "top".. sorry) at .8 shell thickness for extra peace of mind, but only that one; the rest is solid. Print the front and back with the flat parts on the bed. Print the adaptor part with the 45degree part down, like in the STL file.

All you have to do is print it, remove the build in supports (in the adaptor part, the thin columns, in the other two parts, the row of columns on the little overhang). Then you use aluminum/reflective tape everywhere inside, glue the 3 parts together and bingo, you have a ring flash worth 100$ for about 5$ of materials (takes about 50-65 meters of 1.75 filament).

I'll upload a photo of the real deal ASAP. Also, as of publishing time, the STL for the adaptor part is not showing up as an image but can still be downloaded.

If you like, click like, same for "I made one". That's really important to me. feel free to comment.

oh! I attached the 123D file with the clean models and the "supported" models...... if anyone wants to play with it, the only suggestions I have is to figure a better way to attach them together (they were supposed to clip together, but I make the "clips" too small). Also, you might want to reduce the size of the circular, light throwing opening at the top (closer to the flashgun output) since it throws more light (the light not having to go as far before getting out and all. I'd suggest a 25% reduction on top, keep the bottom the same).

title: Bearing Mechanism Lamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hi,

This is the Bearing mechanism lamp!
It's meant to make ever changing light and shadow effects.
It can do this because you can change the lamp shades.
Also you can combine a big and a small lamp shade together.
Additionally they also turn around in opposite directions.
This way you get endless different light reflections on your walls.
In addition I have made different lamp shades to experiment with.
You can use only one shade or experiment with different ones together.
Also different colours give other effects.
If you don't like my lamp shades, you can easily make one your own.

In total I have 4 different (big and small) lamp shades now. See pictures.
You can print them flat on your printer and then roll them up and put them in the base ring.
I had to make each shade in two pieces because not all people have big printers.
You can connect these 2 parts additional with M3 bolts and nuts,
but you may glue nail etc also :-)
As an experiment I also made some lose trees and animals you can push in the rings instead of the lamp shade.

The light source are LED strips I got out of a cheap usb light. See picture.
In my example I used 2 of them, but you can use 4 in total if you wish.
The LED stript are mounted on a bracket with a pivot point so you can adjust the angle.
This way you have more experimental options.
These LED strips work on 5V so its easy to use.

This mechanism is powered by a little stepper and an arduino.
The Arduino script is very easy and I included it with the stepper library and wiring schematic in the ZIP file.
You can change it easely to your own liking. Do not forget to kill power to this little stepper after every move.
otherwise the stepper will get so hot that it will melt the plastic (it's done by the "digitalWrite(IN1, LOW);
digitalWrite(IN2, LOW);
digitalWrite(IN3, LOW);
digitalWrite(IN4, LOW);" commands).
In my case the Arduino and stepper run on 12V.

In the base of this model the print support is already included.
This means you have to cut this away afterwards. See picture (it's the red parts)

Beware: there are two different sizes of cylinders for the bearing part : see picture.

I also made a video in which I try to catch these light effects. But you have to download it first.
Sadly I had to compress the video a lot, for the file size would be to big.
I have also included a lot of pictures if you do not wish to download the video and files

author: Ganesh37

print_settings.Notes:: I've used support only on the blind piece as some infill is needed for where the bearing will be.

description.text:
What is it?

I've put a motor on my roller blinds and made them controllable via MQTT messages or via a web client (two different ways to control the roller blind) that interacts with an on device embedded webserver. I've used the same sized prints for multiple different brands of blinds.

Look at the pictures and animations that will show how it is all fitted together.

I used to have two code bases for an MQTT version and Web client version but I've merged those together into one code base and the use of MQTT is optional. It is set upon WIFI configuration - simply leave the MQTT server field blank.

The current version is for a ceiling mounted roller blind as shown here: https://youtu.be/Dka4of30YOY
How the pieces are assembled: https://youtu.be/3odwHns21Ik

There is a remix made for wall mounted roller blinds made by bmscott. It can be found here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2530155

Additional components

DISCLAIMER: The below description is the parts that I used and how I've assembled it. If you want to use other ESP8266 boards or components it is up to you to test it :-)

  • 1pc. 608ZZ bearing (8x22x7mm)
  • 1pc. tiny screw for center pin fastening the center pin
  • 1pc. 28BYJ-48 stepper motor + ULN2003 driver board. I'm using the 5V version of the motor (but the 12V should give better torque - see my comment below)
  • 1pc. 9v power adapter
  • 1pc. NodeMCU v3 Dev board
  • 2pc. short M4 screws for mounting the stepper motor

Here are examples (including 2 versions of the stepper motor) of items for purchase https://goo.gl/gbb8xT

Hook it up

Connect 9v directly to Vin on NodeMCU board (validate first that your version has a built in regulator for 9V) and to the ULN2003 board. 5V is simply not enough to be able to control the blinds, even with the higher gear ratio, so ULN2003 requires 9V. I'm using the 5V version of the stepper motor and it has worked well for me so far - there's an 12v version though that should be able to give a higher torque than the 5v running on 9v. My roller blind is just 100cm wide and if you have a really wide roller blind I would probably go for the 12V version of the stepper motor. NOTE: A battery will not last long so get a 9V power adapter.
D1 = IN1, D2 = IN3, D3 = IN2, D4 = IN4

Flash the ESP8266-12E

  • Flash your NodeMCU board with code from the following repository: https://github.com/nidayand/motor-on-roller-blind-ws
  • Follow the instructions as described in the Github repository on how to control the device.
  • If you don't have an MQTT server you can use a public one during a testing (!) phase. E.g. iot.eclipse.org:1883 as described here https://iot.eclipse.org/getting-started or simply just just the web client
  • Below are examples of the responsive page served from the device - Android and iPhone UI
  • You will be notified if and when new updates of the code have been released.

Access the web page

Post flashing the device:

  1. Connect to the WIFI Access Point BlindsConnectAP and use nidayand as the password
  2. Enter your WIFI credentials, a unique name for the device (to be used for mDNS) and, optionally, MQTT server details (leave blank if you don't want to use it)
  3. The device will reboot and connect to your WIFI upon save
  4. Use a web browser to connect to the device on port 80. E.g. http://192.168.2.226 or http://{configured_name}.local if you are using an mDNS supported device/client such as iOS or OSX

You want to customize it?

I've thought of doing a wall-mounted version but I don't have that need myself so instead I can share the source code. I've used Autodesk Fusion 360 in the design and you are welcome to download and modify it further as long as you give credits to the original. Download: https://goo.gl/zsPTnC

Credits

  • Ideation from http://www.instructables.com/id/Motorized-WiFi-IKEA-Roller-Blind/ . I wanted a different mount and to get it to work better an increased gear ratio is required and an higher powering voltage to be able to pull the blinds up
  • 24BYJ-48 stepper CAD component. I've done some changes to the original as some distances where off -
    https://gallery.autodesk.com/fusion360/projects/86268/stepper-motor-28byj-48?searched=
  • @Lars Christensen - it is my first Fusion360 design and I used his YouTube channel to learn the basics https://www.youtube.com/user/cadcamstuff/featured
  • Power options for NodeMCU boards - http://henrysbench.capnfatz.com/henrys-bench/arduino-projects-tips-and-more/powering-the-esp-12e-nodemcu-development-board/

Printer:

Velleman k8200

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I've printed all parts in ABS and I'm using a raft only to avoid curling of the gears - otherwise I don't think it is needed.

I've used support only on the blind piece as some infill is needed for where the bearing will be.

comments.text:
Aha, sorry for the misunderstanding. It makes a websocket call to the device so you cannot use wget. Websocket is an open stream protocol. If you have a websocket client you can test with the parameters as defined on row 180-252 (processMsg method) https://github.com/nidayand/motor-on-roller-blind-ws/blob/master/motor_on_a_roller_blind-ws.ino
I've tested with this client: https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/simple-websocket-client/pfdhoblngboilpfeibdedpjgfnlcodoo/related
Connect to e.g. ws://192.168.2.224:81 and send a message. E.g. "res=(update)" and you should get the current position.
Websocket is very lightweight, small headers and the server can send data back to the client without an request.

comments.author: pgote

comments.text: I'm pretty sure that your wiring is not correct - check that you don't have any loose contacts or bad solder joints. If not all LEDs are lit when in use that means that not all coils are getting power or if not all are turned off it is incorrect wiring or bad connections. The motor will get really warm if you have a constant power onto the coils and I've made sure in the code that the power is disconnected when not in use.

"Polish soldiers fight for freedom of other nations but dies only for Poland."

This pack represents all Polish armored vehicles, consisting of at least 10 examples, that fought the 1939 German/Soviet invasion.

description.text:
Materials:

  • 4L sealed box made from PP
  • HDD motor from old 3.5" 250GB WD drive
  • Model aircraft ESC for brushless motors, you may use almost any model, i used Turnigy 20A
  • 12V PSU, 10W is enough (1A)
  • Servo tester, i made one from ESP simply because i don't found pot in components box :)

Motor plate designed in FreeCAD.
Impeller is modified version of Centrifugal impeller, unfortunately i lost source, but modifications are easy - holes to tightly fit on motor outer dia.

To assembly you need cut hole for motor and drill 4+3 holes for M3 screws,
then apply silicone sealant and tight screws. Then check impeller, i used disc spacer ring to mount w/o disbalance.
Then solder ESC wires to motor, there should be 3-phases and (possible) central output, use ohmmeter to find phases (mine have 4 Ohm phase-phase, 2 Ohm phase-center).
Check rotation direction, if it wrong you may change ESC settings (if it supports) or swap any 2 phases.
When all tested to be working i sealed wires with ABS juice (plastic in acetone) and glued impeller with thread lock.

ESP8266 is not required, just i don't have free servo tester, so i made one with MQTT control :)
It connects to MQTT broker (mosquitto), then using MQTT Dash i may control PWM value. "Smart" vapor bath :)

Benefits from HDD motor - it is sealed (use less acetone, no losses via motor hole),
and it is very quiet!

Also i use spear stand for a while, it is useful, but require strong metal backplate.

Place pice of cloth to bottom, it helps to evaporate faster.

title: Prusa i3 MK2 with many revisions

description.text:
Here is my Prusa i3 MK2 based printer. All parts started out as the i3 MK2 (imported from OpenSCAD through FreeCad), and were adapted to suit a MKS Gen controller, and other readily available Chinese parts (power supply, lead-screw nuts, end stops etc). I've added belt tensioners, converted it to bowden with an extruder based on the compact extruder mounted at the top.

LCD housings for regular and full graphic displays are included. X motor can be mounted forward or back. Dual Z endstops are supported (integrated into the motor mounts).

Frame is custom, though mostly similar to the i3, main differences being that I stretched it for 300mm print height, and customised the left-side controller mount holes. DXFs for tall and regular height included.

The heat-bed shown is one I custom designed, based (in concept) on the MK2, but made from aluminium, with PEI cover. Supports 240x240mm printing.

M8 length 205mm
M10 length 425mm
8mm rod lengths, X=350mm, Y=405mm, Z=420mm (or 320mm regular height)
Lead screws are 400mm (or 300mm for regular height)

Power supply is a S-360-12 from aliexpress

Videos:
https://youtu.be/68L9QypX9jo
https://youtu.be/bTQKgKm3bvE

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text:
I made this quick little key-top cover for my Yamaha Aerox Fuel-cap key since the original one broke. This is designed to fit the fuel-cap key ONLY but it may fit other keys aswell.

It's a print-in-place design which means you will insert the key mid-print into the cover and it will be covered by more plastics when print continues. See INSTRUCTIONS for more detailed instructions.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Could be printed in any material. ABS is to prefer due to UV from sun.
Key will act as support

*Start the print as normal. You may want to print the file close to the front as it will be easier to insert the key later.

*In the gcode you will have to add a pause command just before the "covering" layer starts printing. If you do this by height it should be at 4.7mm but if you do it by layer you will have to find the layer where it starts covering(Should be around layer 24 at 0.2mm layer hight).

*When print is paused you just insert the key into the "pocket" that had been printed, the key should fit quite good. I have added a support piece(see pictures) so that the key should lay flat on in the pocket.

*When key is inserted just resume printing. The next layer should cover the key with a layer of plastic.

*Let the print keep going as normal. No more is needed. When print is finished just remove to key-support which already has a .2 gap between the key-cover.

title: Shortened motor bracket - Wanhao Duplicator 6 / Monoprice Maker Ultimate

description.text:
Shortened motor bracket - Wanhao Duplicator 6 / Monoprice Maker Ultimate

This is a modified X/Y axis motor bracket for the Wanhao Duplicator 6 and Monoprice Maker Ultimate. It will increase the distance between the Astrosyn MY17RMDAMP Nema 17 damper and the heat bed.

Print this with a stiff and durable material and use a high infill value!

Installation

  • You will probably need a bit longer M3 screws between the damper and the bracket.
  • You should definately use washers between the two M3 screws/three nuts and the bracket! There is otherwise a high chance that you'll crush the plastic when you tighten the screws and nuts.

Note

There are two versions:

  • "Shortened Motor bracket" is the one I've tested and currently using.
  • "Shortened Motor bracket - untested" is reinforced with a 1mm thick backplate to reduce flex even more. It has holes for the screwdriver. I have not tested this version yet, so please let me know if you try this one!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5820BBUHhKo
Please don’t forget to share your make if you print one.

Thames Dolphin lamp standard’s history goes back to the 19th century. We scanned one of the creatures by taking as many pictures as we could from all possible angles. As we couldn’t cover all the angles, we’ve done some fixing in Autodesk ReMake and sculpting in Meshmixer. It printed very well and it didn’t need many supports. After a huge amount of time spent patching and fixing, we have a lovely replica of the Dolphin Standard.

comments.text: Nice model!  I'm a huge fan of Heraldic/Atlantean Dolphins.  I'm always looking to add to my small collection.  I am curious in your article you mentioned that you wanted to, but could not scan it, for the Scan the World Project (an excellent resource!).  What was the challenge?  I have noticed these particular Thames Dolphin Lamp Posts on the net and would love to give them a try...if I had enough photo resources for a photogrammetry attempt :D
comments.author: Hreodbeorht

comments.text:
Hi Hreodbeorht,
Please find our 3D printable model of the original Thames Dolphin Lamp Standard:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2447152
comments.author: Hreodbeorht

comments.text: I look forward to checking out the file.  Thanks!
comments.author: 3DWithUs

comments.text: Thanks for your comment. Well, the best 3D scan we could achieve still had some holes and the fish was deformed. Maybe we failed because we tried to take pictures on a busy road and didn't pay attention to the quality of all pictures. Another factor could be that the fish was painted in a bright gold paint that might be too shiny for photogrammetry. Anyway, we will make another attempt to scan it at some point.
comments.author: Hreodbeorht

comments.text: Absolutely know what you mean.  I've had some amazing successes with photogrammetry and some absolute fails.  Hard to say what causes it sometimes.  A bright gold subject is a really hard one any way you slice it :D
comments.author: 3DWithUs

comments.text:
Hi again,
Seems like we have a better scan now:
https://twitter.com/3DWithUs/status/878162467435593729
If all goes well there will be an original model soon.

description.text:
(UPDATED WITH PRINTABLE FILES)

This is ChipE Lab Assistant, The assistants features are as follows.

  • Stirring solution while you get on with other tasks, place one or two glass rods in the screw fit holders at the end of ChipE LAs arms place the glass rods into your solution, set ChipE LA to stir mode and leave him to stir away with a gentle stirring motion. You can also make him stir faster in the settings.

  • Probe holder/ Thermometer holder these can be placed with ease at the end of ChipE LAs arms leaving you hands free to write down important information.

  • Setting reminders displayed on the LCD display, at certain times of the day ChipE LA will do a little dance and display your reminder. You'll never miss an important event again.

  • End of day announcement, sometimes your so wrapped up in your Job you don't realize it's time to go home and spend some much deserved time with the family, well now ChipE LA will alert you that it's time to go and recharge your batteries along with it's own.

title: IKEA ALEX/VISDALEN Drawers Ball Bearings Runner Guide

description.text:
Replacement part.
After receiving a VISDALEN chest of drawers, I found this part and ball bearings missing from some of the drawers.
Took a good drawer apart and created this thing from measurements.

How to:
Use pliers to pry open crimped end of slider to insert new part and ball bearings (two at a time).
If missing this part then rails may also need some tweaking back to original shape, look down the length of them to assert the balls will run true in the grooves.

After inserting new part and bearings, bend back the crimped ends to finish.
Good moment to add some grease/lube (that won't eat/soften your filament!) before re-fitting to the drawers.

The ball bearings (24 per drawer) are 3mm diameter and can be found sold as bicycle spares. Online 100pcs can be found shipped anywhere for around a couple bucks.

Enjoy :)

description.text:
I wanted to create a stronger front brace / strut than using stand-offs and also liked the idea of having more protected rear using small sides (to protect the receiver, FPV tx) but without wanting the full weight of a complete side-skirt as others have done.

Both mount to the standard PEON230 frame. The designs don't include a thread as they are reasonably thin pieces and I didn't want to weaken, however I gently tapped (gave it a thread) using self-tapping screws which worked great.

Adds minimal extra weight to the drone, still allows the wires from the ESC's to be thread from the motors and is providing extra protection to the receiver and PDB.

description.text:
Hi folks,

here is my first remix. I took the inspiration from the "Shark comb by Faberdasher, cleaned the shape and create a product family.
For a beardy but creative guy like me, I decided to improve the shark comb, and that I was on the mood, design a beard comb also ;)

The improvements in the shark comb are:

  1. More "user friendly" comb teeth: now these are more rounded and in a spike shape.
  2. Rounded contours
  3. A hole on the tale to hang it on the wall/connect with a ring with the fish-comb
  4. New name: I decided to name it the "Sharky-hair-comb"

The new member of the aquatic combs family is the "Fishy-beard-comb". This have these features:

  1. Fifteen teeth with a distance of 1mm between them
  2. Related shape to the big brother Sharky ;)

I hope you like it and moreover, could fit your needs as they fit mine!

title: Customizable aluminium profile bracket with optional inverted z-motor mount

description.text:
This is the customizable version of the old z-inverting rbase bracket https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2331965. With the mirror option you are now able to create the dual-z motor mount. Also you can adjust the aluminium profile sizes, the wall width, and many other options. It's my first OpenSCAD customizable model.

This design has the Tevo Tarantula in mind, but it can be used for other printers using aluminium profiles and Nema steppers as well. Maybe you'll find some calculation mistakes, I haven't found yet. Please share them with me in order to fix them. My old design was an remix of (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1457449) and (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2137515). Thanks to them for the ideas!

In the files section there is an example stl file as well. Have not printed this for myself, because of the previous version. Let me know if you have created one! Cheers!

title: Charging stand for Huawei Watch 2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My brother bought a Huawei Watch 2, but was annoyed about how much the strap interferes with charging. He asked me about 3d printing a stand, so I told him to look on Thingiverse.

He couldn't find a stand for the Watch 2, but he liked the design for the original Watch published by ahecht... 3 hours later he'd done a bunch of measurements, taught himself Tinkercad and sent me this file to print.

Printed first time.

Potential improvement: The original design has holes in the bottom to add weights... when remixing, these have been distorted... this could be fixed.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Using standard Prusa i3 Mk2 settings in Slic3r. Printed with the side support down on the bed.
